questions.text: Who conducts inquest in Police custodial death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Judicial magistrate

Explanation:

In cases of police custodial deaths, the inquest is conducted by a Judicial Magistrate.

 

In India, there are two types of inquests: police inquest and magistrate inquest.

1. Police Inquest (Section 194, BNSS) (Option A)

  • Most common type of inquest in India.
  • Conducted by a police officer, generally not below the rank of Head Constable.

The police officer, upon receiving information about the unnatural death, visits the site.

↓

Involves two or more witnesses from the local area, called panchas, to assist in the investigation. The report is referred to as a panchnama.

↓

If the cause of death appears to be accidental or non-suspicious, the body is handed over to the family for funeral proceedings.

↓

In case of suspicious circumstances, the police officer forwards the body for a postmortem to a certified medical officer and sends the report to the Magistrate.

 

2. Magistrate Inquest (Section 196, BNSS)

  • Conducted by an Executive Magistrate, or Judicial Magistrate.
  • It's mandatory in specific circumstances, including:
    • Death, the disappearance of a person, or alleged rape in police custody (Option B) or any custody authorized by the court
    • Deaths due to police firing
    • Deaths in jail
    • Deaths of women within 7 years of marriage if,
      • Commits suicide
      • In any circumstances raising a reasonable suspicion that some other person committed an offence
      • Any relative of the woman has made a request on this behalf
      • There is any doubt regarding the cause of death
  • Deaths where there's suspicion of rape before death
  • Deaths with suspicion of foul play or where a relative of the deceased has made a request
  • Also conducted if the case is referred by police due to suspicion arising during their investigation
  • An inquiry by a Judicial Magistrate or Metropolitan Magistrate is required in instances of custodial death, disappearance, or custodial rape where foul play is suspected or there are allegations of an offense. In all other situations, the inquiry can be conducted by an Executive Magistrate.
  • The magistrate is responsible for forwarding the body for postmortem examination to a Civil Surgeon or another authorized doctor within 24 hours of the death.

Feature

Police Inquest

Magistrate Inquest

Conducted by

Police officer

Magistrate (DM, SDM, Judicial, or Executive Magistrate)

Involvement of witnesses

Requires signatures of panchas

Does not require witness signatures

Witness statements

Admissible in court

Not admissible in court

Can order arrest

No, but can arrest in cognizable offenses

Can issue arrest warrants

Exhumation

Cannot order exhumation

Can order exhumation of a body

Autopsy orders

Sends bodies for autopsy indiscriminately

Orders autopsy only when necessary

Forensic analysis

Cannot order chemical analysis of viscera

Can order chemical analysis

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Differences Between Police and Magistrate Inquests:

Medical examiner (Option C) does not conduct inquests.

Coroner (Option D) can not conduct an inquest in police custodial death

choices.text: Causing miscarriage with the consent of the mother
Causing miscarriage without the consent of the mother
Death of the mother by act done with intent to cause miscarriage
Causing the death of the quick unborn child by an act amounting to culpable homicide

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Death of the mother by act done with intent to cause miscarriage

Explanation:

Section 314 IPC

  • Death caused by an act done with intent to cause miscarriage, if act done without woman's consent.
  • Now it corresponds to BNS 90.

IPC Section

Description

312

Causing miscarriage. (Option A ruled out)

313

Causing miscarriage without a woman's consent. (Option B ruled out)

314

Death caused by an act done with intent to cause miscarriage, if act done without woman's consent. (Option C)

315

Act done with intent to prevent a child being born alive or to cause it to die after birth.

316

Causing death of a quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: The court summons a member of the public who witnessed the incident to provide testimony and document their account. What kind of evidence does the witness offer to the court?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Oral evidence

  • “All statements which the court permits or requires to be made before it by a witness, in relation to matters of fact under inquiry, such statements are called as oral evidence".
  • Hence anything which is spoken or expressed by the mouth of a witness who is called for trial in the Court is referred to as oral evidence.
  • Oral evidence is a type of direct evidence.
  • Oral evidence must, in all cases be direct.
  • If it refers to a fact which could be seen, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he saw it
  • If it refers to a fact which could be heard, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he heard it.
  • If it refers to a fact that could be perceived in any other sense or in any other manner, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he perceived it in that sense or in that manner.

Hearsay evidence (Option B): Hearsay evidence refers to a testimony that is provided by a witness and is not based on any personal communication.

Subpoena (Option C): Subpoena is a formal written order that requires a person to appear before a court, or other legal proceedings and testify, or produce documentation.

Circumstantial evidence (Option D): Circumstantial evidence is evidence of facts that the court can draw conclusions from.

questions.text: Who is responsible for handling the investigation in the case of a custodial death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Judicial magistrate

  • Section 176 (l) of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) states that if a person in custody dies or disappears or a woman is raped in custody, the Judicial Magistrate (Executive Magistrate) has the power to order an inquiry.

Conditions for Magistrate inquest:

  • A - Death in Asylum
  • B - Death in hostels
  • C - Custodial death/rape
  • D - Dowry death
  • E - Exhumation

Police Inquest

Magistrate Inquest

174 CrPC

176 CrPC

Most common inquest in India

Best Inquest

 

Type of magistrate Inquest:

Judicial

Executive
  • In the court of law (for conducting trial)
  • Appointed by high court
  • In maintaining law & Order in the society
  • Appointed by state Govt.
  • Designated as District Magistrate (DM)

 

Following govt officials can be appointed as executive magistrate:

  • District Collector
  • Tehsildar
  • RDO
  • Deputy collector

questions.text: When an individual commences employment with a second employer, the new employer assumes responsibility for the individual's actions, under which doctrine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Borrowed servant doctrine

Explanation:

  • The Borrowed Servant Doctrine refers to a situation where an employee is temporarily transferred from one employer to work under the direction and control of another employer.
  • In this case, the new employer assumes responsibility for the employee’s actions while they are under their supervision.
  • Essentially, even though the employee remains on the payroll of the original employer, the new employer has control over the employee’s work and, therefore, is liable for the employee's actions while they are working for them.

Vicarious Liability/ Respondeat Superior

  • Employers are liable for the negligent acts of their employees under certain conditions. Also called the Master-Servant rule.
  • Conditions:
    1. Employer-employee relationship.
    2. Conduct occurs within the scope of employment.
    3. Incident occurs while on the job.
  • Principal doctors can be held responsible for the negligence of their assistants.
  • Temporary Relationships: Surgeons assisting each other may create an employer-employee relationship thus being liable for each other's actions.
  • Borrowed Servant Doctrine: An employee can serve multiple employers (e.g., a nurse assisting a surgeon is a "borrowed servant" during surgery). Negligence occurring due to borrowing of temporary staff from another department.
  • Hospital Liability: Hospitals are liable for the acts of employees under their supervision, but not for senior staff if due care in hiring is proven.
  • Direct Supervision: Physicians are responsible for the acts of interns and residents they supervise.
  • Defense Against Liability: Employers can avoid liability by proving the employee was not negligent or was acting outside the scope of employment.

Incorrect Options:

Vicarious liability (Option A): While this doctrine does involve holding an employer responsible for the actions of an employee, it generally refers to the principal employer's responsibility for their own employees' actions, rather than the responsibility when an employee is temporarily working for another employer.

Doctrine of negligent choice (Option B): This refers to the liability of an employer for hiring an individual who is unfit or negligent in their duties, leading to harm or injury. It does not relate to the responsibility of the new employer for the employee's actions once employed.

Contributory negligence (Option C): This is a defense in tort law where the injured party’s own negligence contributes to their injury. It does not pertain to the responsibility of an employer for an employee’s actions.

questions.text: While recording evidence in the court of law, the opposing lawyer asked the witness, “Did A kill B in your presence?” The witness said, “Yes”. Which procedural route would this type of question be permitted in the court of law?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cross-examination

  • Cross-examination is the correct procedural route in the court of law for this type of question.

Aspect

Examination-in-Chief (Direct Examination) (Option A and B)

Cross-Examination (Option C)

Re-Examination (Option D)

Conducted By

Party who calls the witness (e.g., public prosecutor)

Opposing party (typically defense)

Party who called the witness

Purpose
  • Present all relevant facts
  • Provide expert interpretation if applicable
  • Challenge witness's credibility
  • Elicit favorable facts
  • Test accuracy

Clarify issues raised during cross-examination

Leading Questions

Not allowed unless the witness is declared hostile

Allowed (Sec. 146 BSA)

Not allowed

Nature of Questions

Open-ended questions to elicit narrative

Can include leading questions to control the narrative

Generally clarifying questions

Time Limit

Typically structured and may have time constraints

No set time limit; may last for hours or even days

Generally limited to clarification purposes

Judicial Oversight

Judge may intervene to ensure questions are relevant and not leading

Court can disallow indecent or scandalous questions (Sec. 154, BSA)

Judge monitors to ensure focus remains on clarification

questions.text: Which of the following defines rape?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 375 IPC

Explanation:

Rape definition and conditions

Section 375 IPC (BNS 63) defines rape:

a) Penetrates his penis, to any extent, into the vagina, mouth, urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or

b) Inserts, to any extent, any object or a part of the body, not being the penis, into the vagina, the urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or

c) Manipulates any part of the body of a woman so as to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, anus or any part of body of such woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or

d) Applies his mouth to the vagina, anus, urethra of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person, under the circumstances falling under any of the following seven descriptions:

  1. Against her will
  2. Without her consent
  3. With her consent, only because she or someone she cares about is threatened with harm or death.
  4. With her consent, she mistakenly believes the man is her lawful husband when the man knows that he is not her husband.
  5. With her consent, when, at the time of giving such consent, she cannot understand the nature or consequences due to intoxication, mental incapacity, or being drugged.
  6. With or without her consent, when she is under eighteen years of age.
  7. When she is unable to communicate consent.

Exceptions:

  • A medical procedure or intervention shall not constitute rape.
  • Sexual intercourse or sexual acts by a man with his wife, the wife not being under eighteen years of age, is not rape.

Note: Even if a girl gives consent below 18 years, it is known as statutory rape.

Incorrect Options:

376 IPC (Option B) prescribes the punishment for rape. It outlines the penalties for committing rape, including rigorous imprisonment and fines, with more severe punishments for aggravated circumstances.

377 IPC (Option C) pertains to unnatural offenses, criminalizing sexual acts “against the order of nature” (a historically controversial provision, partially decriminalized for consensual same-sex relations in 2018).

498(A) IPC (Option D) addresses cruelty by husband or relatives of the husband towards a woman. This includes harassment, physical abuse, and mental torture, often related to dowry demands.

questions.text: What is the minimum age at which a woman can give valid consent for Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 18 years

Explanation:

  • In India, the minimum age at which a woman can provide valid consent for a Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) is 18 years.
  • According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, 1971, a woman aged 18 years or older can consent to an abortion independently.
  • Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act: The original act was passed in 1971 and amended in 2021.
  • Indications:
    • Maternal Risk
    • Fetal Risk: Spina bifida, Down syndrome.
    • Eugenic Conditions: Risks to both mother and fetus.
    • Humanitarian Cause: Pregnancy resulting from rape.
    • Contraceptive Failure.

questions.text: As per the MTP (Amendment) Act, 2021, the opinion of two registered medical practitioners is required for termination of pregnancy at which gestational age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ﻿﻿﻿20-24 weeks

Explanation:

  • As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, the opinion of two registered medical practitioners is required for the termination of pregnancy between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation.

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act:

  • The original act was passed in 1971 and amended in 2021.
  • Indications:
    • Maternal Risk
    • Fetal Risk: Spina bifida, Down syndrome.
    • Eugenic Conditions: Risks to both mother and fetus.
    • Humanitarian Cause: Pregnancy resulting from rape.
    • Contraceptive Failure.
  • Qualifications:
    • MBBS, MD/DNB/DGO
    • MBBS who has trained in gynaecology for 6 months
    • MBBS who has performed 25 MTPs under supervision
    • ASHA and AYUSH cannot perform MTP.

 

The MTP Act 1971 and The MTP Act Amendments 2021:

 

MTP Act 1971

The MTP Amendment Act 2021

Indications

(Contraceptive failure)

Only applies to married women.

Unmarried women are also covered

Gestational Age Limit

20 weeks for all indications
  • 24 weeks for rape survivors.
  • Beyond 24 weeks for substantial fetal abnormalities

Medical practitioner opinions required before termination
  • One RMP till 12 weeks
  • Two RMPs till 20 weeks
  • One RMP till 20 weeks
  • Two RMPS 20-24 weeks
  • Medical Board approval after 24 weeks
  • Abortions >24 weeks in cases of significant fetal anomalies with no gestational upper limit - to be decided by a state medical board (gynecologist, pediatrician, radiologist).

Breach of the woman's confidentiality

Fine up to Rs 1000

Fine and/or Imprisonment of 1 year.
